In my opinion, the most offensive portrayal of a character is when they are portrayed as a stereotype. It shows that the people who created the show or the movie don't understand the depths of a character and are shallow people in general. 

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me

In my opinion, the most offensive portrayal of a character is when they are portrayed as a stereotype. It shows that the people who created the show or the movie don't understand the depths of a character and are shallow people in general. 

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype.

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano

In my opinion, the most offensive portrayal of a character is when they are portrayed as a stereotype. It shows that the people who created the show or the movie don't understand the depths of a character and are shallow people in general. 

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype.

In my opinion, the most offensive portrayal of a character is when they are portrayed as a stereotype. It shows that the people who created the show or the movie don't understand the depths of a character and are shallow people in general. 

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype.

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a ste

In my opinion, the most offensive portrayal of a character is when they are portrayed as a stereotype. It shows that the people who created the show or the movie don't understand the depths of a character and are shallow people in general. 

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the most offensive portrayal of a character is when they are portrayed as a stereotype. It shows that the people who created the show or the movie don't understand the depths of a character and are shallow people in general. 

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that w

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stere

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative cogna

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the most offensive portrayal of a character is when they are portrayed as a stereotype. It shows that the people who created the show or the movie don't understand the depths of a character and are shallow people in general. 

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype.

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma ar

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistica

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just on't

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

---

In my opinion, the most offensive portrayal of a character is when they are portrayed as a stereotype. It shows that the people who created the show or the movie don't understand the depths of a character and are shallow people in general. 

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the most offensive portrayal of a character is when they are portrayed as a stereotype. It shows that the people who created the show or the movie don't understand the depths of a character and are shallow people in general. 

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the most offensive portrayal of a character is when they are portrayed as a stereotype. It shows that the people who created the show or the movie don't understand the depths of a character and are shallow people in general. 

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype.

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

In my opinion, the most offensive portrayal of a character is when they are portrayed as a stereotype. It shows that the people who created the show or the movie don't understand the depths of a character and are shallow people in general. 

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

I definitely wouldn't watch a sp

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

I definitely wouldn't watch a specific television show

In my opinion, the most offensive portrayal of a character is when they are portrayed as a stereotype. It shows that the people who created the show or the movie don't understand the depths of a character and are shallow people in general. 

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

I definitely wouldn't watch a specific television show or a movie if a chara

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the most offensive portrayal of a character is when they are portrayed as a stereotype. It shows that the people who created the show or the movie don't understand the depths of a character and are shallow people in general. 

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

I definitely wouldn't watch a specific television show or a movie if a character was being portrayed in a highly offe

In my opinion, the most offensive portrayal of a character is when they are portrayed as a stereotype. It shows that the people who created the show or the movie don't understand the depths of a character and are shallow people in general. 

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

I definitely wouldn't watch a specific television show or a movie if a character was being portrayed in a highly offensive and stereotypica

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the most offensive portrayal of a character is when they are portrayed as a stereotype. It shows that the people who created the show or the movie don't understand the depths of a character and are shallow people in general. 

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

I definitely wouldn't watch a specific television show or a movie if a character was being portrayed in a highly offensive and stereotypical way. I understand th

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the most offensive portrayal of a character is when they are portrayed as a stereotype. It shows that the people who created the show or the movie don't understand the depths of a character and are shallow people in general. 

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

I definitely wouldn't watch a specific television show or a movie if a character was being portrayed in a highly offensive and stereotypical way. I understand that some people use stereotypes to teach a v

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

I definitely wouldn't watch a specific television show or a movie if a character was being portrayed in a highly offensive and stereotypical way. I understand that some people use stereotypes to teach a viewing audience about

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

I definitely wouldn't watch a specific television show or a movie if a character was being portrayed in a highly offensive and stereotypical way. I understand that some people use stereotypes to teach a viewing audience about past culture. 

I also

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the most offensive portrayal of a character is when they are portrayed as a stereotype. It shows that the people who created the show or the movie don't understand the depths of a character and are shallow people in general. 

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

I definitely wouldn't watch a specific television show or a movie if a character was being portrayed in a highly offensive and stereotypical way. I understand that some people use stereotypes to teach a viewing audience about past culture. 

I also find stereotypical i

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

I definitely wouldn't watch a specific television show or a movie if a character was being portrayed in a highly offensive and stereotypical way. I understand that some people use stereotypes to teach a viewing audience about past culture. 

I also find stereotyp

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the most offensive portrayal of a character is when they are portrayed as a stereotype. It shows that the people who created the show or the movie don't understand the depths of a character and are shallow people in general. 

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

I definitely wouldn't watch a specific television show or a movie if a character was being portrayed in a highly offensive and stereotypical way. I understand that some people use stereotypes to teach a viewing audience about past culture. 

I also find stereotypes to be used

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

I definitely wouldn't watch a specific television show or a movie if a character was being portrayed in a highly offensive and stereotypical way. I understand that some people use stereotypes to teach a viewing audience about past culture. 

I also find stereotypes to be used less and less due t

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

I definitely wouldn't watch a specific television show or a movie if a character was being portrayed in a highly offensive and stereotypical way. I understand that some people use stereotypes to teach a viewing audience about past culture. 

I also find stereotypes to be used less and less due to the societal bac

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

I definitely wouldn't watch a specific television show or a movie if a character was being portrayed in a highly offensive and stereotypical way. I understand that some people use stereotypes to teach a viewing audience about past culture. 

I also find stereotypes to be used less and less due to the societal backlash

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

I definitely wouldn't watch a specific television show or a movie if a character was being portrayed in a highly offensive and stereotypical way. I understand that some people use stereotypes to teach a viewing audience about past culture. 

I also find stereotypes to be used less and less due to the societal backlash that comes with it.

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the most offensive portrayal of a character is when they are portrayed as a stereotype. It shows that the people who created the show or the movie don't understand the depths of a character and are shallow people in general. 

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

I definitely wouldn't watch a specific television show or a movie if a character was being portrayed in a highly offensive and stereotypical way. I understand that some people use stereotypes to teach a viewing audience about past culture. 

I also find stereotypes to be used less and less due to the societal backlash that comes with it. An audience isn't go

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

I definitely wouldn't watch a specific television show or a movie if a character was being portrayed in a highly offensive and stereotypical way. I understand that some people use stereotypes to teach a viewing audience about past culture. 

I also find stereotypes to be used less and less due to the societal backlash that comes with it. An audience isn't going to accept offen

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the most offensive portrayal of a character is when they are portrayed as a stereotype. It shows that the people who created the show or the movie don't understand the depths of a character and are shallow people in general. 

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

I definitely wouldn't watch a specific television show or a movie if a character was being portrayed in a highly offensive and stereotypical way. I understand that some people use stereotypes to teach a viewing audience about past culture. 

I also find stereotypes to be used less and less due to the societal backlash that comes with it. An audience isn't going to accept offensive stereotypes in

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

I definitely wouldn't watch a specific television show or a movie if a character was being portrayed in a highly offensive and stereotypical way. I understand that some people use stereotypes to teach a viewing audience about past culture. 

I also find stereotypes to be used less and less due to the societal backlash that comes with it. An audience isn't going to accept offensive stereotypes in movies and TV just

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

I definitely wouldn't watch a specific television show or a movie if a character was being portrayed in a highly offensive and stereotypical way. I understand that some people use stereotypes to teach a viewing audience about past culture. 

I also find stereotypes to be used less and less due to the societal backlash that comes with it. An audience isn't going to accept offensive stereotypes in movies and TV just because they're pla

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

I definitely wouldn't watch a specific television show or a movie if a character was being portrayed in a highly offensive and stereotypical way. I understand that some people use stereotypes to teach a viewing audience about past culture. 

I also find stereotypes to be used less and less due to the societal backlash that comes with it. An audience isn't going to accept offensive stereotypes in movies and TV just because they're playing a character.

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the most offensive portrayal of a character is when they are portrayed as a stereotype. It shows that the people who created the show or the movie don't understand the depths of a character and are shallow people in general. 

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

I definitely wouldn't watch a specific television show or a movie if a character was being portrayed in a highly offensive and stereotypical way. I understand that some people use stereotypes to teach a viewing audience about past culture. 

I also find stereotypes to be used less and less due to the societal backlash that comes with it. An audience isn't going to accept offensive stereotypes in movies and TV just because they're playing a character. The character has

In my opinion, the most offensive portrayal of a character is when they are portrayed as a stereotype. It shows that the people who created the show or the movie don't understand the depths of a character and are shallow people in general. 

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

I definitely wouldn't watch a specific television show or a movie if a character was being portrayed in a highly offensive and stereotypical way. I understand that some people use stereotypes to teach a viewing audience about past culture. 

I also find stereotypes to be used less and less due to the societal backlash that comes with it. An audience isn't going to accept offensive stereotypes in movies and TV just because they're playing a character. The character has to have depth to them. 

Stereotypes ar

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

I definitely wouldn't watch a specific television show or a movie if a character was being portrayed in a highly offensive and stereotypical way. I understand that some people use stereotypes to teach a viewing audience about past culture. 

I also find stereotypes to be used less and less due to the societal backlash that comes with it. An audience isn't going to accept offensive stereotypes in movies and TV just because they're playing a character. The character has to have depth to them. 

Stereotypes are wrong. They're j

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

I definitely wouldn't watch a specific television show or a movie if a character was being portrayed in a highly offensive and stereotypical way. I understand that some people use stereotypes to teach a viewing audience about past culture. 

I also find stereotypes to be used less and less due to the societal backlash that comes with it. An audience isn't going to accept offensive stereotypes in movies and TV just because they're playing a character. The character has to have depth to them. 

Stereotypes are wrong. They're just a way to get a

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the most offensive portrayal of a character is when they are portrayed as a stereotype. It shows that the people who created the show or the movie don't understand the depths of a character and are shallow people in general. 

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

I definitely wouldn't watch a specific television show or a movie if a character was being portrayed in a highly offensive and stereotypical way. I understand that some people use stereotypes to teach a viewing audience about past culture. 

I also find stereotypes to be used less and less due to the societal backlash that comes with it. An audience isn't going to accept offensive stereotypes in movies and TV just because they're playing a character. The character has to have depth to them. 

Stereotypes are wrong. They're just a way to get a cheap reaction ou

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

I definitely wouldn't watch a specific television show or a movie if a character was being portrayed in a highly offensive and stereotypical way. I understand that some people use stereotypes to teach a viewing audience about past culture. 

I also find stereotypes to be used less and less due to the societal backlash that comes with it. An audience isn't going to accept offensive stereotypes in movies and TV just because they're playing a character. The character has to have depth to them. 

Stereotypes are wrong. They're just a way to get a cheap reaction out of a viewing audience. Some direc

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

I definitely wouldn't watch a specific television show or a movie if a character was being portrayed in a highly offensive and stereotypical way. I understand that some people use stereotypes to teach a viewing audience about past culture. 

I also find stereotypes to be used less and less due to the societal backlash that comes with it. An audience isn't going to accept offensive stereotypes in movies and TV just because they're playing a character. The character has to have depth to them.

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

In my opinion, the most offensive portrayal of a character is when they are portrayed as a stereotype. It shows that the people who created the show or the movie don't understand the depths of a character and are shallow people in general. 

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.

Stereotypes are wrong. They're just a way to get a cheap reaction out of a viewing audience. Some directors take pride in their work, and sadly some d

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the most offensive portrayal of a character is when they are portrayed as a stereotype. It shows that the people who created the show or the movie don't understand the depths of a character and are shallow people in general. 

There are many stereotypes in TV and film that make me cringe. A racist white man, a "gangster" black man, a dumb blonde all come to mind for me.  These characters are just directors taking the easy way out. The characters have no depth. The stereotype they are portraying is their personality.

That is very offensive to me. I understand why these roles are used in TV and film but it still bothers me if their entire character is just the stereotype. 

There are some stereotypes that work for me. Tony Soprano was the stereotypical mob boss. He was a stereotypical Italian male with an ego. But he also had depth to him. He showed vulnerability. He went to a therapist. He had anxiety. He had depression.

The entire depth of his character wasn't that he was a stereotypical Italian. You kind of forgot about that while you were watching the show. 

That to me is a stereotype done right, even though stereotypes have a negative stigma around them. And realistically, all stereotypes are negative. Some just don't offend me to a great extent.
